outputs.output_descr: This Management project captures the coordination, monitoring, reporting and advocacy components that contributes to the over-all delivery of the regional governance programme. It also provides a mechanism to cover the transitional elements from ARGPI into ARGPII, including important initiatives in the Parliamentary Strengthening and Electoral Support service lines that are currently being completed and considered important contributions to the current programme.

donor_name: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade of the Republic of korea
outputs.output_descr:
National governments are better able to align external sources of development finance (including ODA and climate change finance) with their own planning and budgeting systems to strengthen development effectiveness in pursuit of the MDGs [revised output statement following the project revision - August 2011]

Countries in Asia-Pacific increase the accountability and effectiveness with which they use their aid to achieve MDG targets. Countries better able to contribute to and influence the outcome of the Fourth High Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness in Korea in November 2011.

Policy-makers in key ministries and non-state parties are better able to develop effective governance arrangements for MDG acceleration strategies and climate change through local government [revised output statement following the project revision - August 2011]

UN country teams will be equipped to address governance issues of MDG acceleration in UNDAFs, programming implementation, and support for national MAF processes. In response to country needs, relevant practices will be supported to implement MDG Acceleration Frameworks targeting off-track MDGs. Governance expertise will be effectively brought up to the MDG Acceleration agenda. Support will be given to regional analysis, tools, and processes.

Capacities of national and regional institutions, including justice sector-related institutions and stakeholders are strengthened to deliver and enhance access to justice and promote human rights. [revised output statement following the project revision - August 2011]

The project will work with ministries of justice, women's machineries and civil society groups, including women's groups and networks with respect to enhancing capacities for the implementation of international conventions including CEDAW and ESCR, particularly with regards to how they relate to MDG acceleration and achievement. National Human Rights Institutions and Women's Human Rights Institutions will be engaged to build their capacities to discharge duties with respect to the promotion and protection of human rights. The project will also work with sub-regional human rights bodies such as in ASEAN Intergovernmental Commission on Human Rights and the ASEAN Commission on Women and Children by distilling and disseminating lessons fro other regions on good practices and examples of required policy, institutional and regulatory frameworks that might be adapted for the ASEAN context.

For the Regional Center in Bangkok, this DGTTF regional allocation provides a strategic opportunity to consolidate the lessons and knowledge on democratic governance innovations supported by the DGTTF.  It allows APRC to systematically analyze the conditions and factors which foster innovation, how these are further leveraged, as well as seize opportunities for new breakthroughs in democratic governance programming.  The regional allocation will also facilitate a rapid response mechanism for the APRC governance team to address emerging CO demands in democratic governance.

donor_name: IBM is the world's largest information technology company, and the world's largest consulting services organization.

the world's largest enterprise software company, Oracle is the only vendor to offer solytions for every tier of your business-database, middleware, business intelligence, business applications. and collaboration.
outputs.output_descr: Enhance inclusive participation of all stakeholders, particularly the most disadvantaged and marginalized to deepen democratic processes from the demand-side.

State and non-state actors have increased capacity to enhance the voice and civic engagement of excluded groups in democratic governance and work to widen democratic space [revised output statement following the project revision - August 2011]

State and non-state actors are capacitated to harness communication mechanisms (access to information policies, e-governance, and media) for enhanced government transparency and effectiveness

donor_name: United Nations Office on Drug and Crime
outputs.output_descr:
State and non-state actors are capacitated to support implementation of international instruments, norms and standards to increase integrity in governance. [revised output statement following the project revision - August 2011]


The implementation of the UN Convention on Anti-Corruption (UNCAC) will be further promoted and supported. Emerging issues in the region related to anti-corruption will be addressed particularly through the analysis of the links between anti-corruption and climate change progamming and anti-corruption and achieving the MDGs. Countries will be supported to assess their progress in combating corruption by measuring corruption and monitoring anti-corruption efforts, including the different impacts of corruption on men and women and the different opportunities for corruption for both men and women.

project_descr: Asia Regional Governance Programme; Phase II
project_title: Asia Regional Governance Programme; Phase II
